div.head: Cornfield, 2,000 years old.
div.p: We have received photographs of crops of grain, sown in autumn last at the Deir in Khargeb, on a plot of land, five or six acres in area, belonging to the Corporation of Western Egypt. The crops, which consist of wheat and barley, look excellent, and were respectively reaped on April 16 and March 31 ultimo, What is phenomenal about this land is its marvellous fertility; there are positive proofs to show that the land has lain fallow since Ptolemy, 2,000 years ago, and yet despite the fact that not an ounce of manure was used, it has after this lapse of time yielded an excellent crop of wheat. The fact is worthy of a place in Egypt's history.

div.head: To Abolish the Egyptian Mosquito.
div.p: The canals and birkets in Egypt are great breeding grounds for the mosquito and it is of interest to hear of a West Indian method of extermination which could be introduced into this country. In the Barbadoes many of the waters abound in a small fish known as "millions" -presumably from their great numbers - which feeds on the larvæ of the mosquito. It is said that in the parts where the fish abounds there is immunity from mosquitoes, and that malaria is almost unknown. Experiments are to be tried by introducing the fish into other islands of the West Indies. This plan of introducing a natural enemy has proved successful in a number of cases, and the mosquito-eating fish might be introduced into other districts. If this fish really feeds largely on the larvæ of the mosquito, and if the latter have really become extinct in the district, we have the unusual case of species exterminating its own food supply.

div.p: The members of the Alexandria Literary, Musical and Dramatic Society should not miss Mr. R. Williams' lecture at the Sailors and Soldiers' Institute on Monday next on the above subject. div.head: LORD MILNER.
div.p: BANQUET IN LONDON.
THE NATION AND ITS SERVANTS.
(Gazette's Special Service).
LONDON, Saturday.

The banquet, which was appropriately held on the evening of "Empire Day," in honour of Lord Milner, was a magnificent, while not excessive, tribute to a great career. Mr. Chamberlain, who was in the chair, made a great speech in which he pointed out that Lord Milner and such as he sought not popular applause but were content to leave the judgement of their work to posterity. He said that Lord Milner, far from being poor, was opulent in the only kind of wealth which he valued, namely, the esteem and respect of a great body of the nation, and, far from being powerless, he was only awaiting the time when his services would again be required. Meanwhile, he was one of the Empire's great assets.

Lord Milner met with an enthusiastic reception on rising to make his reply, which was modest and rightly conceived. He said he believed that it was characteristic of the British nation, despite the exigencies of party, to deal with its servants in a spirit of broad generosity, and whilst not demonstrative in recognising their faithful services, did not go to the other extreme of noting small things done amiss but rather dealt with the merits of their service as a whole.

div.head: BOUNDARY COMMISSIONERS SAIL.
div.p: THE DIANA AT ALEXANDRIA.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez Thursday.
H.H. cruiser Nour-el-Bahr sailed from Suez at noon to-day for Akaba with the Egyptian boundary commissioners.
As advised you yesterday, the cruisers Fox and Perseus sailed for Aden yesterday afternoon. They are bound to the Persian Gulf.
H.M.S. Diana, which has played a prominent part at Akaba, entered the Canal at 8 o'clock this morning bound to Alexandria.

H.M.S. Diana arrived at Alexandria early this morning from Suez, and anchored in the outer harbour. Rear-Admiral Lembton, who had been staying at San Stefano, shortly afterwards proceeded in a steam launch to join the vessel, on which his pennant was at once hoisted. The Diana then sailed, presumably for Malta.

The Diana bore the burden and heat of the day in the recent frontier dispute, having been sent on a special mission by the Commander in-Chief of the Mediterranean Fleet at the outset of the difficulty, accomplishing a delicate diplomatic mission with success, and to Lord Cromer's satisfaction. Her commanding officer, Captain R. S. Phipps Horoby, though only thirty-nine, has a record of much active work, and has before been engaged on special service in Creta and in Tangier. He also is familiar with Egyptian problems, having served in the Egyptian War in 1882, and is recognised as a promising and able young officer, following well, as opportunity occurs in the steps of his distinguished father.

div.head: THE CASE OF FRAULEIN MILEWSKA.
div.p: HER ARREST IN CAIRO.

The arrest in Cairo some time back of Fraulein Milewska and the events that led up to it are still occupying the attention of the Berlin law courts. This complicated case of Fraülein Milewska, who was maid of honour to Princess Amalia of Schleswig Holstein, has been occupying the Garman courts for the past six years. It received a further hearing last week.

Fraulein Milewska, as has previously been reported, is being tried for extensive embezzlement, and slander of her royal mistress. The case is going against the maid of honour, who in her turn, however, has now brought a suit against Herr von Blumenthal, Chamberlain of the German Kaiser, who effected her arrest in Cairo. She states that in order to have her arrested Herr von Blumenthal made slanderous statements concerning her to the Egyptian authorities, including allegations as to her identity as head of an Anarchist band. Fraulein Milewska also asserts that Herr von Blumenthal falsely represented in Cairo that her arrest was the direct desire of the German Kaiser himself.
It was this phase of the case, Fraulein Milewsks's accusations against the-Kaiser's Chamberlain, Herr von Blumenthal, which received a hearing last week.
The case was adjourned till further witness can be procured.

div.head: PORT SAID'S GRIEVANCES.
div.p: NEW MARKET WANTED.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Port Said Thursday.

The local paper "La Vérité” has recently drawn attention to many grievances at Port Said, besides pointing out several abuses in native bazaars, such as unstandardized weights and the insanitary condition of certain districts in the European quarter. Special mention is made of the custom of throwing slops into the street. One resident in Port Said has been known on occasion to carry an umbrella, when there was practically no rain, remarking to facetious enquirers, "What price the slops"! Time after time people just miss being bespattered with dirty dish and other water en passant. The lack of urinals or latrines forbids any interference with those who give offence to the more sensitive passengers unacquainted with native customs. Port Said is practically the only point in Egypt at which passengers en route to and from the East touch, to say nothing of numerous fastidious American tourists. It is a pity such an omission should have been allowed to continue so long. Residents are accustomed to these sights and possibly from the hygienic point of view there is little amiss with the present method of solving the question of sewage disposal.

With regard to the bazaar, the provision of a new market built on modern lines for the sale of fish, meat, vegetables and other goods liable to rapid decomposition in our climate would go far to remove the present unsatisfactory state of affairs.

div.head: ANGLO-AMERICAN NILE STEAMERS AND HOTELS CO.
div.p: At the annual general meeting of the above company, which was held in Cairo yesterday, it was decided to distribute a dividend of six and a-half per cent.

In regard to the company's land at Boulac, we understand that the area embraces about 8,000 square metres, which, at a very conservative estimate of its total value, should be worth at the very least £50,000.
The following is the report of the directors for the past year's working up to the 30th ult.

In preparing their sixth annual report and balance sheet the directors, though satisfied that the general business of the company has on the whole been maintained, have felt the absence of any special sources of profit which made last year one of exceptional prosperity and enabled them to declare a larger dividend than usual. A further reduction of profit has to be recorded under the heading of freight : the return on the capital invested in this branch of business has fallen to a point inconsistent with any further reduction in rates. The directors hope that the present tariff may be maintained, but, should the competition in rate cutting be further indulged in, they may be obliged to adopt a policy which, while entailing some temporary loss and inconvenience on their shareholders, will effectively put an end to the practice.

Experiments have been made during the past year in the construction and equipment of sailing barges and their employment in river and canal traffic. The great difficulty of controlling native crews whose riverain origin makes them desirous of prolonging, rather than of ending their voyages, is largely responsible for results, which, if not altogether constituting a failure, cannot be regarded as otherwise than a qualified success. The doubt attaching to the outcome of any experiment seems to justify the policy of the directors in refusing to embark in capital expenditure of any magnitude without first assuring themselves, as far as such a thing is possible, that it will be permanently remunerative. It may, and does mean, that a portion of the capital of the company remains unengaged. It is however possible to find temporary remuneration for capital outside the business of the company, and in this connexion the directors are able to point to the successful employment of the reserve fund which has produced a very considerable profit. This fund, which after last year's additions amounted to L.E. 12,000, has now been brought up to L.E. 17,000 by the premium derived from the issue of 5,000 shares to the Hamburg-America Line. The investment, as last year, appear in the balance sheet at cost price ; the depreciation on the Crédit Foncier shares is counterbalanced by the appreciation in the value of the Menzaleh shares, but no account has been taken of either.
AGREEMENT WITH HAMBURG-AMERICA LINE.

The arrangement arrived at with this important Company, of which details were given at the extraordinary general meeting, is one which will, the directors believe, be to the advantage of the shareholders. A considerable economy is expected from the concentration of the European agencies in the hands of the Hamburg-America Line, while the additional tourist traffic which they should secure, should contribute largely to the success of the new steamboats which are to be put on the Nile. There boats are being built in England and will, it is hoped, be ready for the coming tourist season.

Want of space in the Company's yard at Boulac and the difficulty of providing in so limited a space an ares both for the requirements of modern and efficient workshops and of a ware-housing depôt, led the directors to seek for a suitable site elsewhere ; the price of land in the near vicinity of Cairo suitable for the purpose is now almost prohibitive, but they are happy to say that they have obtained from the Ministry of Finance a lease of three feddans of land at Shoubra for a period co-extensive with the existence of the company. This site, although somewhat distant, is, nevertheless, well adapted to the company's requirements by virtue of its long trontage on and depth of water in the Nile channel. A considerable outlay will have to be incurred in erecting adequate premises and workshops. The directors, however, hope to be able to provide for this by the sale of a portion of their site at Boulac. After writing off the value of the present workshops and such plant as cannot be removed and making provision for the new premises, it is expected that a considerable surplus will be available. This will be devoted to further strengthening the position of the company by the creation of those special funds without the protection of which no navigation company can be said to be properly safeguarded.

div.head: THE VICTORIA COLLEGE
div.p: ITS INCEPTION.
To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir,--You will excuse the liberty I take in thus writing you these lines, but seeing that H.E. Lord Cromer laid the foundation stone of the New Victoria College yesterday, I thought perhaps you would like to know the history of the first establishing of this school, in which you and every Englishman take such a great interest.

By birth I am not an Englishman, but I have been in connection with the Britishers for nearly 50 years, coming amongst them as a boy, and all my thoughts, my interests and feelings are with that race. I am now about 64 years of age, and whatever I have, even to my existence, I owe to them, and I do not regret it, because they have treated me always as one of their own countrymen.

I was sent out here by the Church of Scotland Mission Society in the year 1877, I believe. I began and continued my work earnestly but it was most difficult as there was no English schools everything was foreign. French, Italian and German schools there were, and no one seemed to have any sympathy with the English, who by other nationalities seemed to be hated and despised. The above nationalities taught only their own language in their own schools. Consequently I began to worry the life out of the late lamented Sir Ch. Cookson and the late lamented Canon Davis, of St. Mark's Church for nearly 5 years. These two gentlemen I was so often with them, that I was taken as part and parcel of them, they were great and true friends of mine. I asked them, why don't you get the English Government to build a good English school here, which is so greatly needed ? The reply was that the English Government did not build schools in foreign countries, and told me I should not worry myself to death about the matter, that my heart was too soft, and if I did not take care my head would be the same. I did not care, I thought if the English Government would not help with a day school, I would by the help of my two friends' financial help start a night school. I did, and had over 150 adults and boys. I was obliged to pay English teachers and I asked Professor Alf. Griffen and another Englishman who has since died at Constantinople to come and help me. Syd. H. Carver, Esq.. Judge Lionel Sanders, Sir. Ch. Cookson, apd Canon Davis provided me with the means to pay the teachers and to pay all expenses, which I kept up for over 3 years and it was a great success. In the end I was sorry to give the night school up owing to Sir Ch. Cookson leaving Egypt as the means at my disposal after he left were not sufficient to keep it going.

The year before he left though I was so persistent, and not going to be daunted I would not leave the good Sir Charles alone, until I had got by hook or by crook a day school, until in desperation be said, "Well, Rudolph, if you can encourage some rich Jews to take an interest in the school you can have your heart's desire and we will make it a good one." I was delighted. I brought Clement Aghion to Sir Charles Cookson, and we talked the matter over, especially upon finance Clement Aghion got his relative Giuseppe Aghion and Baron Menasce to join, and the Victoria College was first established by Sir Ch. Cookson, Clement Bohor, and Gioseppe Aghion, Baron Menasce, and the late Canon Davis, and I pride myself upon being the originator of the scheme, when I amongst the many others behold the foundation, the corner stone of which H.E. Lord Cromer laid, one of the finest schools in Egypt.
Professor Alfred Griffen can bear me out and testify to what I have said to be true, with regard to the establishment of the school.-- Believe me, etc.
P. Rudolph
Asile Rudolph, Alexandria, May 25.

div.p: La question du jour dans le monde de la Bourse est le refus que vient d'opposer la Corporation des agents de change à la demande d'admission à la cote de la Gharbieh Land.
D'après l'article 22 des statuta de la Corporation des agents de change nous voyons :

En dehors des valeurs déjà reconnues et dont le tableau signé par le Président de la Corporation est affiché à la Bourse, aucune nouvelle valeur ne pourra être admise à la cote officielle de la Corporation, si son introduction n'a pas été préalablement étudiée par le comité, pois votée par l'assemblée générale.

Les Sociétés constituées en vue d'une industrie nouvelle pour le pays ou dans un bat de spéculation ou désignant dans leur objet un programme qui ne serait pas limité ou qui serait trop général ne pourront être admises qu'après une période de fonctionnement de une a trois années et après appréciation du bilan annuel, du bénéfice distribué et de la réserve établie.

Cet article institue le pouvoir exclusif des agents de change qui peuvent toujours accuser une société, si sérieuse soit-elle, d'avoir on bat de spéculation pour la renvoyer d'année en année, jusqu’au jour où des preuves irréfutables de sa bonne constitution les obligent de l'accueillir.

La Gharbieh Land est une des sociétés les plus sérieuses que nous ayons, son objet ost "l'achat, l'amélioration, l'exploitation et la vento de terrains notamment dans la province de Gharbieh"; en un mot c'est une société dans le même genre que la Behera aveo un capital inférieur.
